canonical_explanation.text: Heights and Distances is an application of trigonometry to solve real-world problems involving vertical and horizontal distances. The angle of elevation is the angle formed between the horizontal line and the line of sight when looking upward at an object. The angle of depression is the angle formed between the horizontal line and the line of sight when looking downward at an object. These problems typically involve right-angled triangles where we use trigonometric ratios (sine, cosine, tangent) to find unknown heights or distances. Problems may involve a single right triangle or multiple right triangles requiring multi-step solutions. Standard angle values (0°, 30°, 45°, 60°, 90°) are commonly used for exact solutions.
rules: Angle of elevation is measured upward from the horizontal
Angle of depression is measured downward from the horizontal
In a right triangle, tan(θ) = opposite/adjacent = height/distance
In a right triangle, sin(θ) = opposite/hypotenuse
In a right triangle, cos(θ) = adjacent/hypotenuse
The angle of elevation from point A to B equals the angle of depression from point B to A
Always draw a clear diagram to represent the problem
In multi-step problems, solve one triangle at a time
Units must be consistent throughout the problem

questions.question_text: Arrange the steps for solving: 'A man walks towards a tower at uniform speed. The angle of elevation changes from 30° to 60° in 5 minutes. How long to reach the tower?'
ordering_items: Let height = h, initial distance = d₁, final distance = d₂
Write tan(30°) = h/d₁, so d₁ = h√3
Write tan(60°) = h/d₂, so d₂ = h/√3
Distance covered in 5 min: d₁ - d₂ = h√3 - h/√3
Time to reach = d₂/speed = (h/√3)/[(h√3 - h/√3)/5]
Simplify to get final time
